TopicTitle: From Kerbin to the Mun (Sort of a Space Odyssey)

Articles.Content:
FROM KERBIN TO THE MUN

(or 'When We Were Lemmings')

Sort of a Space Odyssey, staring Major Jeb

With Reluctant Participation by Bill and Bob Kerman.

1.

President John K Kennerson stood in front of the assembled Kerbal Kongress. A motley crew indeed. The place reeked of perspiration and cheap aftershave.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Stooges,Ã¢â‚¬Â he muttered to himself, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Booger-Eaters. A bunch of mindless political hacks who would sell their own mothers to the Kraken if they thought it would help them get elected.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The President's words boomed through the somewhat-tastefully decorated post-neoclassical hall of power. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Er, Mr. President,Ã¢â‚¬Â an aide whispered, Ã¢â‚¬Å“That mic is hot.Ã¢â‚¬Â

None of the Kongressmen noticed. They were too busy picking their noses, checking their voice mails, negotiating the sales of their mothers, and pretending to admire (while secretly sneering at) the knots in each others' ties.

President Kennerson tapped on the mic, sending painful waves of feedback echoing through the auditorium. Aggrieved and injured Kerbals clutched their ears and looked resentfully up toward the podium.

The President was in his element. His handsome green skin gleamed with confidence. He blinked as several dozen flashbulbs went off at once. His stomach growled. What would he have for lunch?

Ã¢â‚¬Å“My Fellow Kerbals,Ã¢â‚¬Â he began, Ã¢â‚¬Å“I believe that this nation should commit itself to the goal, before next week is out, of landing a Kerbal on the Mun!Ã¢â‚¬Â More flashbulbs. Thunderous applause. The aide whispered in Kennerson's ear. Ã¢â‚¬Å“And, ah,Ã¢â‚¬Â the President went on, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Returning him safely to Kerbin!Ã¢â‚¬Â His last words were lost in the applause and general hubub.

Kennerson's stomach growled again. So hungry! He was sick and tired of peanut butter-and-jelly sandwiches. What should he have for lunch?

A journalist raised his hand. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mr. President, what will the name of this new space program be?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“A ham and cheese sandwich,Ã¢â‚¬Â The hungry president mused.

The next day, the newspaper headlines screamed Ã¢â‚¬Å“HAM AND CHEESE TO THE MUN!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

2.

The mood in the kerbonaut ready room was glum. The boys had just finished their tour of the Vehicle Assembly Building, and Bob and Bill were not impressed. Wernher Von Kerman had proudly shown them what they had assumed was a hastily built, rough scale model of a prototype spacecraft. The thing appeared to have been thrown together with plywood, aluminum foil, and bailing wire.

Von Kerman quickly disabused them of that notion as he proudly showed off his creation, the Ham and Cheese I, it's paint still tacky and the whole contraption smelling strongly of fresh sawdust and Bondo.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Um, where is the center of thrust?Ã¢â‚¬Âasked Bill.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And what is the specific ISP of those... er, engines?Ã¢â‚¬Â put in Bob.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You fellows ask such interesting questions!Ã¢â‚¬Â beamed Von Kerman.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“What safety features does this thing have? What happens in the event of a structural failure or an abort?Ã¢â‚¬Â asked Bill.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is there going to be an escape tower or an ejection seat or parachutes or anything?Ã¢â‚¬Â asked Bob.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You young fellows use such big words!Ã¢â‚¬Â Von Kerman said happily, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Such fine vocabulary! The tour is over. I really must get back to work. After all, tomorrow is Launch Day!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Back in the ready room, Bob and Bill looked at each other and shook their heads. What poor sap was going to get stuck flying in that monstrosity?

The toilet flushed with a space-age roar, and Jebediah Kerman came out of the bathroom, wearing his customary idiotic grin. The zipper on his flight suit was wide open, and a toilet paper flag waved merrily from the bottom of his space-boot.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hi guys! Did I miss anything?Ã¢â‚¬Â

3.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is a test flight,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill explained to Jeb, Ã¢â‚¬Å“You'll be blasting off into Low Kerbin Orbit.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“That means you'll circle the planet,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob explained patiently.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“If, um, all goes well, you'll orbit three times, try some maneuvers in zero-gravity, perform a retrograde burn, and, ah... splash down safely in the ocean.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“On the off chance you survive, you'll be famous.Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob added helpfully, Ã¢â‚¬Å“The first Kerbal in space!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb nodded wisely and smiled. He liked Bill and Bob. Such nice guys. And so smart! They know some really big words.

4.

The KSP Kerbonaut Transfer Vehicle (an old Pinto spray-painted white) rolled up to the pad, backfired twice, and stalled. Jebediah Kerman stepped out, eyes bulging, an idiotic grin plastered plastered all over his face. He waved cheerfully at the assembled journalists.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Poor sap,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill Kerman back in Mission Control. Ã¢â‚¬Å“He's a goner.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“A dead man,Ã¢â‚¬Â confirmed Bob, sipping his coffee. They watched on the monitor as Jeb ascended the tower, waved one last time for the cameras, and entered the command module. A technician secured the door and scurried hurriedly away to a safe distance.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now remember your pre-flight instructions,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill Kerman over the radio, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Fasten your seatbelt, sit still, and don't touch ANYTHING.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Inside the command module, Jebediah Kerman twiddled his thumbs and fidgeted impatiently. 'Gosh, this is exciting!' he thought. 'I should have peed before I got into this thing...'

The radio crackled with terse conversation from Mission Control.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“T-minus fifteen minutes,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill.

'Good old Bill,Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb thought, 'He's really smart. I like him.'

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Systems check,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill went on. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Propulsion?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Go!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Guidance?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Go!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Avionics?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oops! Dropped my slide-rule.... Er, um, go!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Medical? ... Medical...? Somebody wake up Slim!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, uh, sorry. Uh... medical, go. I guess.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Roger Kerman, the guidance officer, looked up from his clipboard. Ã¢â‚¬Å“What?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not you,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill said. Ã¢â‚¬Å“T-minus twelve minutes. SAS on.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“What?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Never mind. Throttle to 100%. We're on internals.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb fidgeted and squirmed. This was taking forever. They'd told him not to touch anything. They'd been most emphatic on that point. But that big red button taunted him. So large. So shiny-red. So tempting...

Ã¢â‚¬Å“T-minus eight minutes and counting... what the...?!?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Smoke bellowed and belched out of the Ham and Cheese I. The craft trembled and shook. A powerful shock wave knocked the assembled press corps flat on their backs.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, boy,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill to Bob, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now he's gone and done it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“He's dead,Ã¢â‚¬Â confirmed Bob.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Holy cats...Ã¢â‚¬Â exclaimed Bill, Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think it's actually lifting off!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“WHAAAAAAA!Ã¢â‚¬Â hollered Jebediah Kerman, Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is awesome! This is fantastic! I'm flying! This is the greatest day of my life! I'm King of the World! Um, how do I turn this thing off?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You're passing ten thousand meters,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill said over the radio, Ã¢â‚¬Å“trajectory um... nominal! Looks like you're go for orbit! It's a good thing we convinced Von Kerman to put a parachute on that thing. Stand by for stage separation.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“What do I have to do?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nothing!! Fold your hands and place them in you lap. Remember what we told you in the pre-flight briefing?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know, I know... 'Don't touch anything'.Ã¢â‚¬Â

There was a hideous rending tear, a flash of light, and a puff of smoke high up in the sky. Ã¢â‚¬Å“OK, stage separation confirmed. Second stage motor... start. Jeb, you still with us? Looking good.... Jeb, you moron, what are you doing?!?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm flying!Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb's voice crackled over the radio, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Whee! This is fun!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Trajectory flattening out...Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said, Ã¢â‚¬Å“his nose is pointing down. Silly nit. So much for that orbital trajectory.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's the last of his fuel. Engine shutdown confirmed. Final stage separation... and go. Huh, I wondered who packed the parachute?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, that would be Gilrim Kerman.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well that could be good or bad. Depending on the day of the week, and how much he'd had to drink. Oh well, we'll find out in a minute. Somebody pour me a fresh cup of coffee.Ã¢â‚¬Â

5.

To everyone's surprise, the big white parachute performed flawlessly, poofing open 800 meters above a sapphire-blue ocean. The command module of the Ham and Cheese I splashed gently down, carrying one excited and very much alive Jebediah Kerman.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I did it!Ã¢â‚¬Â he proclaimed, stepping out of the capsule onto the deck of the hastily-converted Space Vehicle Recovery Barge (formerly garbage scow). Ã¢â‚¬Å“The First Kerbal In Space! I'm a hero! A super-hero!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Um Jeb,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said, Ã¢â‚¬Å“You do realize that you were just a passenger, right?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Essentially ballast,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill put in.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks guys,Ã¢â‚¬Â Jebediah beamed, Ã¢â‚¬Å“you fellows are the greatest. And you use such big words!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, let's have a group hug,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Wernher Von Kerman who had just stepped up with the official photographer. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Next stop, The Mun! And I've already selected the crew...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh boy,Ã¢â‚¬Â lamented Bill through clenched teeth.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh dear,Ã¢â‚¬Â confirmed Bob with a heavy sigh.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh GOODY!Ã¢â‚¬Â exclaimed Jeb, squeezing his crew-mates tight and grinning idiotically. Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're going to The Mun!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Stage Separation Confirmed

End Part One.

FROM KERBIN TO THE MUN

Part II: The Ostrich Has Landed

Sort of a Space Odyssey

1.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“So...? Vhat do you think?Ã¢â‚¬Â Wernher Von Kerman looked at the two kerbonauts expectantly. The Ham and Cheese III towered above them, piercing the roof of the Vehicle Assembly Building. Technicians were busily applying duct tape and Bondo to the ungainly contraption.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's really...Ã¢â‚¬Â began Bill.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“...Big.Ã¢â‚¬Â finish Bob.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ja!Ã¢â‚¬Â beamed Von Kerman. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ve had to cut a hole in the roof just to make it fit.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob and Bill looked at each other. Meh, he'll figure it out for himself when it was time to move the craft to the launch pad.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“So um,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill, Ã¢â‚¬Å“What happened to the Ham and Cheese II?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ugh,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Von Kerman, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Don't ask. Now, since Jebediah Kerman is the most experienced kerbonaut, he vill be mission commander.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Great...Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill and Bob together, rolling their eyes.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ja!Ã¢â‚¬Â Von Kerman continued happily, Ã¢â‚¬Å“It vill be, how do you say it, one big happy family up there, ja? Now zee next step in the process is to fill the tanks with highly explosive rocket fuel. Ah, here comes Gimblet Kerman with the fuel truck now!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eh, gotta go!Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bill, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Left a pie in the oven!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Er, um...Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said, uncomfortably shifting from foot to foot as he watched Gimblet fumble with the fuel hose, Ã¢â‚¬Å“...see you later, Doctor!Ã¢â‚¬Â

2.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“What do you mean I'm not covered for space travel?!? I'm a kerbonaut!!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill Kerman was on the phone with his life insurance agent.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh boy guys, this is going to be great!Ã¢â‚¬Â Jebediah Kerman's eyes were popping with excitement, an idiotic grin plastered all over his clueless green face. Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm bringing Scrabble, I'm bringing Twister, we can play charades...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob Kerman had a space-age ball point pen in hand, and was filling out his Last Will and Testament. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Darn KSC pen doesn't even write right-side up! This thing is useless!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“30 seconds to blast off. Secure all loose items.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill and Bob put away their phones and pens and tightened the buckles in their harnesses. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now remember what they said in the pre-flight briefing Jeb...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know, I know...Ã¢â‚¬Â Jebediah looked momentarily crestfallen. Ã¢â‚¬Å“'Don't touch anything'...Ã¢â‚¬Â He brightened up, the customary idiotic grin returning to his sunny green face. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, I snuck my banjo onboard!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“3... 2... 1... IgnitionÃ¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“NOOOOOOOO!Ã¢â‚¬Â Yelled Bob and Bill simultaneously as the great engines roared to life, crushing them back in their seat cushions, and Jeb began plucking out a very battered rendition of 'She'll be Coming Round the Mountain'.

3.

*several hours later. The Mun looms large in the capsule windows*

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I wish all three of us could go down there... maybe if one of you sat in the other's lap...?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob and Bill rolled their eyes. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now Jeb, we've been over this several times already.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know, I know. There's only room for two in the munar lander, and someone has to stay to pilot the command module. Too bad. It's going to be really pretty down there... Which one of you is coming with me?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You know, we hadn't thought about this issue..Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill said.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah,Ã¢â‚¬Â said Bob, as they watched a quarter tumbled in midair, Ã¢â‚¬Å“flipping a coin in zero-G is kind of problematic...Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few minutes later, Bob (having lost the coin toss) and Jeb were safely ensconced in the Ostrich, the munar landing module.

Bills voice crackled over the radio, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good luck fellows.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“We don't need luck,Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb responded. Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm piloting this thing!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey Jeb,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said, Ã¢â‚¬Å“didn't you have to bail out of the Ham and Cheese II yesterday?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah,Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb said. [more-or-less an actual Neil Armstrong quote]

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Radar altimeter on-line,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob reported, Ã¢â‚¬Å“1000 meters and dropping... Jeb, are you paying attention?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Look at me! I'm flying upside-down!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“500 meters. 30 seconds of fuel remaining...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“100 meters. Rate of descent 25 meters per second. 10 seconds fuel remaining...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I can make it do a loop-de-loop!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“20 meters... and engine flame-out. Brace for impact...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wheeee!Ã¢â‚¬Â The spacecraft made contact with the munar surface. The Ostrich bounced twice, threatened to tip over, didn't, bounced a third time, and finally came to a rest on the vast munar plane. The landing gear, which had performed admirably so far, gave a sigh and sheered off, leaving the Ostrich balanced precariously on it's engine exhaust nozzle.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Ostrich has landed.Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb said, his head swelling visibly with pride. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Let's go for a walk!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Um Jeb,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said as Jeb started unlocking the landing module door, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Shouldn't we pressurize our space suits first?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right, good idea!Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb never stops grinning, does he?

The two kerbonauts clambered carefully out of their space ship.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, shouldn't you say something historic?Ã¢â‚¬Â asked Bob.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Holy #@$% #@$% !!Ã¢â‚¬Â said Jeb, Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're walking on the #@$% Mun!!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

They planted a flag, and gathered up a few mun rocks.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's beautiful... magnificent desolation...Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Kind of boring,Ã¢â‚¬Â Jeb said, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Where are all the trees? Let's get back in the Ostrich and blast off back home.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh Jeb...Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said, but Jeb wasn't listening.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“All systems go or whatever... 3-2-1-BLAST-OFF!! Ã¢â‚¬Â¦ why isn't anything happening?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Um Jeb,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob sighed, Ã¢â‚¬Å“You ran us out of fuel when we landed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh...Ã¢â‚¬Â said Jeb, slightly crestfallen.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I say we split up,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said. Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'll stay with the lander, you go look for help.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm in command here, and you'll do what I say, darnit! ...I say we split up. You stay here with the lander, I'll go look for help.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Whatever you say, Boss...Ã¢â‚¬Â

4.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm about to initiate my trans-munar burn.Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill crackled over the radio. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hang tight down there Bob, I'm sure Von Kerman will send a rescue pronto.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Rodger that,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mun Base Ostrich out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

5.

Jeb was tired. He had been walking a long, long time. He couldn't even see the Ostrich anymore. Good old Bob. He's really good at Scrabble. He knows such big words. The jerry can was heavy in Jeb's hand. He switched hands, smiled and kept on walking. Ã¢â‚¬Å“There's got to be a gas station around here somewhere...Ã¢â‚¬Â

6.

'So long, suckers,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bill Kerman thought to himself. He was on a free return trajectory. All he had to do was one short retrograde burn, survive re-entry, and he was all set. 'As soon as I get down,' he thought, 'I'm retiring. Get me a good ghostwriter and hit the talk-show circuit.'

Methodical engineer that he was, Bill went through the pre-retroburn checklist out loud: Ã¢â‚¬Å“RCS- set. Navigation Computer- set. Throttle to 100%. Parachutes... parachutes... #@$% ?! Damn you Wernher Von Kerman, you forgot the parachutes!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill did a quick course correction and plugged the numbers into the navigation computer. The good news was that he wasn't going to burn to death while he plunged through Kerbin's atmosphere. The bad news...

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Look at that apoapsis... sheesh, they didn't even teach us numbers that big at the Kerbal Mail-Order Institute of Technology. And what's my orbital period? ...wow... it's going to be a long, lonely flight. At least I'll have some piece and quiet for a change.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Twenty minutes later, Bill was already missing Jeb and his Scrabble set. But not the banjo.

Stage Separation Confirmed

End Part Two

FROM KERBIN TO THE MUN

Part III: Like a Mun Over Troubled Waters.

Sort of a Space Odyssey

1.

The Mun is pockmarked with craters. It is a vast wasteland of craters. Impact craters that are kilometers wide, and craters the size of a dime. Craters within craters. Craters that have been there for billions of years. And others that arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t nearly so old.

The wreckage from the latest impact was still glowing. Ã¢â‚¬ËœNuclear engines? TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re really grasping at straws back in Kouston, arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t they?Ã¢â‚¬â„¢

Bob Kerman sipped his Bubbly Bounce Beverage and watched as a grey-suited figure climbed laboriously out of the latest crater, staggered, spun unsteadily around, and collapsed.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“The nice thing about a vacuum,Ã¢â‚¬Â he commented aloud to himself, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is that you donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have to hear them scream.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Far above the Ostrich I, a tiny point of light was quickly growing bigger and brighter. The latest rescue ship. It was coming in like a meteor, burning full throttle. Bob could have turned on the radio and listened to the panicked chatter, but that had long since grown stale. He watched as the doomed craft described a ballistic arc across his field of vision, finally crashing a couple of hundred meters from where he sat on a deck chair improvised from solar panels. The vibrations from the impact rattled his molars.

A few seconds later, a large square package nearly beaned him. It was orange nylon fabric, neatly folded and crisply creased. It contained a little handwritten note that read: Ã¢â‚¬ËœPacked by WVKÃ¢â‚¬â„¢. A parachute.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh Jebediah,Ã¢â‚¬Â Bob said to himself, Ã¢â‚¬Å“You may have been a goon and a total knee-biter, a blithering idiot even, but I almost miss you. He never got tired of playing Scrabble, but never played a word longer than three letters either. And oh, that banjo. I do *not* miss that banjo. He was one hell of a pilot though. He could land a washing machine if Von Kerman strapped a thruster to it. In fact, I think he did. I wonder whatever happened to old Jeb?Ã¢â‚¬Â

2.

Jebediah Kerman had been walking for a long, long time. Forever, in fact. Behind him, across the dusty gray wasteland of the Mun, his footprints trailed off to the horizon.

Where was he supposed to be going? He couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t quite remember. What was he supposed to do when he got there? He was unclear as to that detail as well. Surely he would get there soon. HeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d been walking a long, long, long time, and his legs were getting tired.

He was holding a jerry can in one hand. Oh yes, that was it, they had run out of fuel, and he was looking for a gas station. There must be one around here somewhere.

Blinking lights, just this side of the horizon. Ah, at last, a filling station! HeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d get fuel, and bring it back to the Ostrich. WouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Bob be pleased?! Good old Bob! But first, heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d use the facilities. Stupid spacesuits should come with a built in bladder or something.

High above him, Kerbin hung in the sky like a beautiful blue and green marble. An idiotic grin brightened JebÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sunny green face as he trotted cheerfully toward the distant structure.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I hope they take credit cards!Ã¢â‚¬Â

3.

Bill Kerman slipped out of KerbinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sphere of influence with a soft sigh and a gentle yawn. The wreckage of JebediahÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s banjo floated aimlessly through the capsule. Bill suspected that he might be going crazy. Just a little bit. But mostly, he was bored.

Mission control had been suspiciously vague about the rescue mission, and the auxiliary telemetry thingamabob had started making an annoying hum that rattled through BillÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s bulging eyeballs. Behind him, through the viewing port, Kerbin was a tiny dot of light. Bill gnawed at his fingernails, and discovered he had none left to gnaw.

WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s this?! A glossy magazine rolled up underneath JebediahÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s seat. Something? Anything! Bob picked it up and read the title. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Kollywood Unklothed: Naked and Nude CelebritiesÃ¢â‚¬Â? What the hey?

Final transmission from the command module Ham and Cheese III:

Ã¢â‚¬Å“My God! ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s full of stars!Ã¢â‚¬Â

4.

Funny looking gas station. It looks just like a space ship.

As Jeb got closer and closer, he became more and more convinced. It was a space ship. The good old Ostrich I, to be exact. There was Bob, sitting on a pile of solar panels, sipping a beverage.

Jeb grinned idiotically and jogged toward the Ostrich, empty jerry can swinging aimlessly in his hand.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Boy, oh boy, wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Bob be surprised to see me!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Stage Separation Confirmed

End Part Three

wow this is so awesome and funny, hahah poor jeb had to circle the mun by foot

btw are you making more of this?

Ã¢â‚¬Å“My God! ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s full of stars!Ã¢â‚¬Â

I see what you did there. Nice writing too!

FROM KERBIN TO THE MUN

Part IV: Gravity is a Harsh Mistress

Sort of a Space Odyssey
